intro: Myriocladus simplex, commonly known as the desert dandelion, is a flowering plant native to arid regions of the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that resemble dandelion blooms. The plant has a low, sprawling growth habit with dark green, fleshy leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. Its flowers are typically yellow, and it produces small, white to pale yellow seeds that are dispersed by the wind. Myriocladus simplex is well adapted to dry environments, with features such as succulent leaves and deep root systems that help it conserve water.
